009package imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.ellipse.algebraic;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012
013import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
015
016import ij.IJ;
017import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
018import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
019import imagingbook.common.math.eigen.GeneralizedSymmetricEigenSolver;
020
021/**
022 * 
023 * Algebraic ellipse fit based on Fitzgibbon's original method [1], 
024 * as described in Halir and Flusser [2] (WITHOUT their numerical
025 * improvements). Based on generalized eigenproblem solution.
026 * 
027 * Does not use data centering nor accepts a specific reference point.
028 * 
029 * [1] A. W. Fitzgibbon, M. Pilu, and R. B. Fisher. Direct least-
030 * squares fitting of ellipses. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis
031 * and Machine Intelligence 21(5), 476-480 (1999).
032 * 
033 * [2] R. Halíř and J. Flusser. Numerically stable direct least squares
034 * fitting of ellipses. In "Proceedings of the 6th International
035 * Conference in Central Europe on Computer Graphics and Visualization
036 * (WSCG’98)", pp. 125-132, Plzeň, CZ (February 1998).
037 * 
038 * @author WB
039 *
040 */
041public class EllipseFitFitzgibbon implements EllipseFitAlgebraic {
042        
043        private final double[] p;       // = (A,B,C,D,E,F) algebraic ellipse parameters
044        
045        public EllipseFitFitzgibbon(Pnt2d[] points) {
046                this.p = fit(points);
047        }
048
049        @Override
050        public double[] getParameters() {
051                return this.p;
052        }
053        
054        private double[] fit(Pnt2d[] points) {
055                IJ.log("**** " + this.getClass().getSimpleName());
056                final int n = points.length;
057
058                // design matrix X:
059                RealMatrix X = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 6);
060                
061                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
062                        double x = points[i].getX();
063                        double y = points[i].getY();
064                        double[] ri = {sqr(x), x * y, sqr(y), x, y, 1};
065                        X.setRow(i, ri);
066                }
067                
068                // scatter matrix S:
069                RealMatrix S = X.transpose().multiply(X);
070                
071                // constraint matrix C:
072                RealMatrix C = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(6, 6);
073                C.setEntry(0, 2, 2);
074                C.setEntry(1, 1, -1);
075                C.setEntry(2, 0, 2);
076                
077                // solve C*p = lambda*S*p  which is equiv. to 
078                // A*x = lambda*B*x (A, B symmetric, B positive definite)
079                GeneralizedSymmetricEigenSolver eigen = 
080                                new GeneralizedSymmetricEigenSolver(C, S, 1e-15, 1e-15); 
081                                // low ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD (last argument) is important!
082                
083                double[] evals = eigen.getRealEigenvalues(); 
084                int k = getLargestPositiveIdx(evals);
085                double[] p = eigen.getEigenVector(k).toArray();
086                
087                return Matrix.normalize(p);             
088        }
089        
090        // ------------------------------
091        
092        private int getLargestPositiveIdx(double[] x) {
093                double maxval = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
094                int maxidx = -1;
095                for (int i = 0; i < x.length; i++) {
096                        if (Double.isFinite(x[i]) && x[i] >= 0 && x[i] > maxval) {
097                                maxval = x[i];
098                                maxidx = i;
099                        }
100                }
101                return maxidx;
102        }
103        
104}
